title: Medical Definition of Smallpox vaccine
author: Medical Editor Charles Patrick Davis; MD; PhD
description: Read medical definition of Smallpox vaccine
cleaned_text: Smallpox vaccine: A vaccine that contains a live [virus](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=5997) called [vaccinia](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=21861) that is used to prevent smallpox. The vaccine does not contain the [variola](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=6257) virus that causes [smallpox](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=6328), but exposes the [immune system](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3907) to [proteins](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=15380) that look like the virus so that an [immune response](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3906) occurs. Through the use of the vaccine, smallpox was eliminated from causing human [infection](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=12923) [in](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3950) the world in 1977. Routine [vaccination](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=5925) against smallpox ended in 1972. The level of [immunity](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3908) among persons who were vaccinated before 1972 is uncertain. In people exposed to smallpox who are not [immune](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3905) to the [disease](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3011), the vaccine can lessen the severity of or even prevent the illness if given within 4 days of exposure.
